utterance: Wilson Smith: Yeah. So, so we we talked about this in in the last subgroup is that, you know, at at NREL we've done technoeconomic and life cycle assessments of different pathways for, you know, full air to barrel scenarios. And as you scale up CO2 electrolysis, whether you use uh something like Opus 12, which is a PEM electrolysis in in acid or something like dioxide, which is alkaline. Um as you scale this up to, you know, more than 10 to 50,000 units of production, the major cost in both of those systems is the membranes. So the idea of, you know, the power's cost is not uh it's it's nothing, even the bipolar plates are a small thing, separations aren't too bad if we can do this well. But for both of them, the real limiting step is the cost of membranes and both the the base materials but then also the manufacturing at large scale. So I think that's where we can kind of, you know, look at which, you know, how did batteries get 10x cheaper in 10 years? Was it the cathodes that got cheaper? Was it the better electrolyte? I think we can learn, you know, like people have said from these other fields, how did they improve efficiency, reduce costs, usually to material components or stability or durability and and for electrolyzers, we I mean, all the modeling points in any case, whether we do this in alkaline conditions, the membranes are going to be the driver for for the cost.

utterance: Wilson Smith: So um the the first question for the kind of um the first discussion was life cycle assessment. Now for technoeconomic assessment, um we actually do a sensitivity analysis to see which operational or material parameters would lead to the biggest shift in cost. And there we see that the biggest drivers are the single pass conversion efficiency and the current density. Now the issue with that is that if you look in literature, those are things where it's kind of like whackable. If somebody can do very good current current density, they have very low single pass conversion. If they have very good single pass, they have low current. So in the end, you ideally would like them both and then that is to us a frontier is that how can you do both of those things at the same time? And that takes I don't think that that's going to be solved by a cascade reaction. I think that's going to be reactor engineering and process integration that's going to solve that not not a cascade on the catalyst. Can I try and translate that, you know, to, you know, as a chemist into activity versus selectivity? Is that what you mean?

annotations.reject idea: The speaker rejects the idea that a cascade reaction will solve the problem of achieving both high current density and single pass conversion.

utterance: Wilson Smith: It's reactor design and um again the electrolyte. So if you're doing CO2, um even if you start with a basic electrolyte, if you start to run it more than 10 or 20 milliamps, it's going to become alkaline spontaneously. So it's the electrolyte consumption, but then with the with the kind of transport control, there are things like pressure drops that will change and it depends on if you're making CO2 to CO, so a gas feed stock to a gas product, the the pressure drop across the electrode will be small. But if you want to make a liquid product, you will create a much bigger pressure drop across your electrode and the effects down the channel will be much more significant. So it's there there's a lot of competing factors, which is why I think, you know, CO2 electrolysis won't scale the same way that water electrolysis does. You know, selectivity is not an issue for water electrolysis.
